Award.AwardTitle: Measure theory and geometric topology in dynamics
Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the goals of dynamical system theory is to understand the orbit structure of systems displaying some particular feature. In this project the principal investigator will focus on dynamics displaying some sort of hyperbolicity. The project will develop in two main directions, dynamical systems with multidimensional time (i.e. actions of higher rank groups) and positive entropy and classical dynamical systems (i.e. one dimensional time) displaying some uniform (though possibly partial) hyperbolicity. The aim is to develop techniques to understand the interactions between measure theoretical and topological properties of a system. This interaction happens to go both ways. For instance, in the direction of topology to measure theory it is observed that on 3-dimensional nilmanifolds partially hyperbolic systems are always K-systems. And in the direction of measure theory to topology it is known that a non-uniformly hyperbolic higher rank action on a 3-dimensional irreducible manifold can only exist on the torus.


Boltzmann's study of gas particles produced the nowadays accepted idea that several systems display some chaotic behavior. While the system may be of very diverse origin, e.g. from mechanical, biological, stock-market, etc., their abstract mathematical model can hopefully be classified and then studied with various mathematical technologies. The aim of this project is to classify systems displaying some hyperbolic behavior, the hallmark of chaotic dynamics, and prove that such systems should have some algebraic origin, thus introducing a purely mathematical and very powerful technology into the study of an otherwise intricate problem. While chaotic behavior is by definition impossible to be deterministically predicted, algebraic systems present symmetries that allows the researcher to study the long run behavior, and be able to describe the orbit structure of such systems. The PI plans to continue with the formation of graduate students, the writing of preparatory material on the subject (e.g. books, survey papers, lecture notes, etc.) and collaborate with the teaching of mini-courses, organization of workshop, seminars, etc.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the goals in Dynamical Systems theory is to understand the orbit structure of systems displaying some particular feature. This project focused on systems displaying some hyperbolic behavior. The type of systems we worked with came in two flavors: the ones where the time runs linearly and the ones where the time has more complicated group structure and are in general called group actions. 
Let us first discuss the second situation. The theory of group actions have flourished in the second half of the 20th century. It have shown to have very strong impacts in several areas of mathematics as Number Theory, Lie Group Theory, Geometry, etc. When the group acting has a rich algebraic structure it is expected that the action display some sort of rigidity. Rigidity in this context refers to the fact that the system should admit a very clear description, in general in some algebraic terms. This philosophy is far from being completely fulfilled but there are several examples of it that we shall describe. One particular example of this rigidity philosophy is known as Zimmer conjecture that states that a higher rank lattice in a semisimple Lie group acting in small dimensions should act trivially.  The work of the PI and his collaborators have lead to the solution of a very important case of this 40 year old conjecture by A. Brown, D. Fisher and S. Hurtado. 
Another instance of such philosophy is the Theorem shown by The PI joint with A. Brown and Z. Wang that shows that an action of higher rank lattice in a semisimple Lie group acting on a torus and admitting a hyperbolic element is algebraic. This by itself relies on the result by the PI and Z. Wang on rigidity of higher rank abelian hyperbolic actions on tori.
In the case of higher rank abelian group actions, when the rank of the group is 1 less than dimension of the ambient space, the PI with A. Katok showed (under some mild hyperbolicity assumption) that the action has to be measurably algebraic  and moreover get very strong constrains on the topology of the underlying  manifold. 
In the setting of standard Dynamical Systems, the PI joint with A. Gogolev and P. Ontaneda showed new examples of partially hyperbolic systems on simply connected manifolds in dimension 6. This was a long standing problem. In the setting of hyperbolic systems this is still widely unknown (and people do not expect such example to exist). In the setting of partially hyperbolic system, it has been shown by D. Burago and S. Ivanov that this is impossible in dimension 3. (In dimensions 2 and 4 is impossible by obvious obstructions.) Dimension 5 remains the big problem now. 
Also in the theory of partially hyperbolic systems, the PI with J. Rodriguez Hertz and R. Ures, have shown examples of systems with non-integrable center distribution (also a long standing problem). This contrasts heavily with the work of D. Burago and S. Ivanov where some almost integrability property is produced. 
There is also an intermediate class of systems, known as the random systems that consists on random iteration of different systems. One of the reasons to study such a system is that when it comes to real experiments the researcher necessarily make some rounding mistakes so one cannot assume anymore that one is iterating the same system. To model this phenomenon the random systems are one of the best options. In this theory, the stationary measures are the measures that describe the the asymptotic behavior of the system. Following work by Y. Benoist and J-F. Quint on one hand and A. Eskin and M. Mirzakhani on the other hand, the PI and A. Brown were able to show, when the ambient space is 2-dimensional, that under some mild assumptions the stationary measures are SRB measures. These are probability measures that have very important geometric properties that make them simpler to compute and thus understand the long run property of the orbits. It also give a very clear picture of the chaotic properties of the system.

Let us mention that most of the work related to this project has been done with mathematicians in the first years of their career. We believe that this is one of the best ways to get the techniques developed to reach further impact.
